title: Delta 6" Professional Joiner Depth Setting Replacement Knob

description.text:
Do you own a Delta 6" Professional Joiner?  Did you recently move?  During the move, did the movers break the joiner depth setting knob?  If you answered yes to all the questions, then this thing is for you!
Actually, my wife and I recently moved, the movers broke the depth setting knob on my Delta 6" Professional Joiner, and I designed and 3D printed this replacement.  The photograph shows the old broken knob, and the 3D printed replacement installed on the joiner (with the initials "GLZ").  I printed the prototype at high speed (150%), and at .2mm layer height with 10% infill, so it appears a little rough, but it works.  I had planned on printing the final version at standard speed, .2mm layer height with 100% infill, but the prototype worked just fine.
I seriously doubt anyone will download or even print this thing, but I posted it to show that if a 3D printer is good enough for making certain replacement parts for a professional woodworking machine, who knows what's next.  I can imagine in the future replacement parts are only a download away.
Designed using Sketchup Make 2015, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" Settings (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill).

description.text:
This is a scalable version of the carrying pouch I've made for my Leatherman Wave. I've made these for years and it's the handiest design I've come up with. I am in the process of re-making it since my last one was lost :-(   so I decided to publish it here.  
It's a bit weird for Thingiverse since you don't need a CNC device to make it, but it's a scalable digital file, so I guess it belongs.  
Opens in Inkscape. A video on the actual construction will follow.

Select the pattern in the middle and scale the X and Y to fit your multitool. It has very little "ease-" (fits tightly).   
Scale it mathematically from the length and width of your preferred multitool- the Wave is 4" long by 1.5" wide by 1/2" thick. Scale the Y by the length of the multitool, scale the X by the sum of the width and thickness. (So if the tool is 4.5" long, scale the Y to 112.5%). Print it out.  
Add ~3/8" seam allowance all the way around and cut it out of ballistic nylon, canvas, or other heavy material.  
Cut reinforcement, webbing, and velcro to the new scaled lengths. The standard 3/4" width should be fine for most things unless you scale it down so far you need to use 1/2" wide webbing and velcro instead. Likewise scale the partially-shown long webbing designated by an "X".  
Fold over and finish the two short ends, then sew on the velcro and webbing bits (zigzags on the pattern represent bar-tacking to hold the webbing on), fold it in half and sew the long edges.   
In use, the long webbing strap goes behind your belt, underneath the cross-ways webbing, then up and over to attach to the top flap and then to the velcro down the front. This allows you to put it on and take it off w/o removing your belt, but it can't fall off like a clip can.  
It also allows you to pass the long strap obliquely through a belt loop at the same time so that it can't migrate back and forth when you're crawling around in an attic or crawlspace. This makes it hang somewhat obliquely so you don't get poked in the spleen when you bend over or squat.  
If this doesn't make sense the video will be coming along just as soon as I can get it shot.  
Inspired by a nameless tool holder I had about 25 years ago; it eventually wore out and I've been making them ever since.

title: RCExplorer Tricopter V3 Tarot T-2D Gimbal Mount

description.text: This is a simple and effective way to mount a Tarot gimbal on your RCExplorer Tricopter. There is no cutting or drilling of either the tricopter or the gimbal. Everything can be put back the way it was. Since the gimbal is mounted to the isolated "clean plate" the rubber bobbins from the gimbal are no longer needed. To reduce the possibility of gimbal induced vibration due to the clean plate almost being too flexible, I used a single earplug wedged between the gimbal mount and the front spacer on the tricopter. This acts as a shock absorber and keeps everything stable. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5w3V3m_GlXY UPDATE Version 1.2 (probably final) I moved the gimbal control board to the front of the mount to alleviate the problem of the wires not being quite long enough. With the roll motor pushed into the mount to where the back of the motor is flush with the back of the mount; the roll arm just clears the gimbal control board. Version 1.1 is now up which includes an integrated gimbal control module mount and a thicker bottom strap. The "mount controller" is no longer need but I left the files in case someone can use it. I also upload the reverse side of the mount controller. The only issue I see with this version is the wire that runs from the IMU to the controller board is a touch too short. It will work for everything except pointing the camera straight down. I am probably going to tweak the design further to try and gain a little more slack.

title: Animatronic Body Bag
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Here's a short video if the final product Parts designed for making a wriggling body bag for Halloween. You'll need: Prints:
Spine Disk x 8
Servo Mount x 1
Servo Pulley x 2 Hardware:
Futaba S3004 Servos x 2
3/8" Poly Tubing for spine
1/16" Wire Rope
1/16" Aluminum Ferrules
Foam Tube for Body
Bolt that screws tight inside tubing
Arduino Uno
Adafruit Motor Shield V2
Adafruit Audio FX Board (if adding sound effects)

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Play

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes: Support is necessary for the Servo Mount.

Step 1 Transfer the hole pattern from the servo mount to the wood plate and drill the holes. Step 2 Drill a slightly undersized hole in the wood plate and screw the large bolt/screw through the servo mount and the wood plate. Step 3 Screw the poly tubing onto the bolt/screw, then slide the spine disks down the tubing and space them equally. Secure the top disk with a nail or screw. No need to glue the other disks. Step 4 Run the steel rope through the hole, through the spine disks, then secure at the top using the ferrules. Step 5 Drill holes in the servo pulleys to accommodate the steel rope. Center your servos. Using the included disk horn, screw this to the servo pulleys and mount. Feed the steel rope through the holes and secure with ferrules while under slight tension. Step 6 Use the attached Arduino code to run the servos at random. Connect the servo leads to the servo pins on the Motor Driver board. Step 7 Use foam tubing to create a life-like "body." Wrap in trash bags and hang it from a tree in your front yard. Scare kids.

description.text: For Oreos, the bitter crunch and the unruffled sweet call for an inevitable indulgence. But what keeps you coming back for more? The cookie or the crème? The two components might just be incomplete without the other and we all have different preferences to enjoy “Milk’s Favorite Cookie.” The Oreo Dipparator will ease your devouring experience of the Oreo. Simply poke the Oreo Dipparator into your Oreo (grasping the separator) and release to separate the cookie and crème! Sick of getting milk stains on your hands when you have to reach deeper to dip the Oreos? The Oreo Dipparator works as a cookie dipper as well! Oreo Dipparator from Voravit Vorapanyasakul on Vimeo.

remixed_from.title: Ultimate 38mm Rotating Spool Holder - MakerBot Replicator 2

title: Filament System Spool Holder For Robo 3d R1 +Plus

description.text:
NOTE: IF YOU USE HATCHBOX FILAMENT THIS WILL NOT WORK FOR YOU. Reel hole diameter is smaller than this spool holder. This is my second re-mix of this excellent spool holder. The original I did for my Makergear M2. I've used several Thingiverse items to put this filament handling system together for the Robo 3D R1 +Plus. The systems consists of the following:
  • Rotating spool holder
  • Rotating spool holder mounting base
  • Metal plate to mount the base to the plastic robo housing
  • Filament guide to guide the filament up towards the top of the Robo
  • PTFE tubing
  • Two filament dust filters. One with a sponge inside to clean the filament (mounts between the reel and filament guide (not shown in the picture)). Another that mates with the Robo filament guide on top of the Robo cover but WITHOUT A SPONGE. The sponge can keep the filament from retracting properly so I'm only using this one as a guide for the filament and to mate with the PTFE tubing. See instructions on how to mate it. Here's the link to download the filter STL's: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:704809
  • Hardware
    • The spool holder is sized for most large 5lb reels. 52mm slide-on adapters are included for the more standard smaller reels. Also, I have included a Taulman Reel adapter that slides on the spool holder and has a separate smaller spool holder for the taulman reel. Please see my original re-mix of this spool holder for information on sourcing bolts and washers to complete the item, the instructions are included in the images of that item: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:523415 You'll also find many more pictures there. The only part not mentioned in my original remix is the metal plate that I used to mount the spool holder base to the Robo Housing. I used this in order to try to avoid stress to the plastic Robo housing. Not sure if it will help, but it definitely can't hurt. Stainless Steel Sheet Metal 16 Gauge .060" 304 #4 (brushed finish) 2" x 2". I purchased it on eBay from this supplier: http://stores.ebay.com/SheetMetalsOnline?_trksid=p2047675.l2563 It mounts on the inside of the Robo housing. You will need to drill four holes into it using the rotating spool holder base as a guide. Also be careful that the screws you use to mount it don't get in the way of any moving parts on the Robo! I will probably be making revisions to this post in the next few days. I think I've covered everything but will probably add a few more details. The spool holder turns smooth as silk, you may actually need to overtighten the bolt a little bit to create some friction to slow it down. Definitely takes the load off the stepper motor. You will need to ream out the spool holder with a good wire brush to size it just right on the bolt. I made it a little tight on purpose to allow for a nice snug fit on the bolt. So the wire brush will be needed. My original re-mix has more detailed instructions regarding setup: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:523415

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Medium to High

Infill:

High

Notes: I used .3mm layer height for the spool holder and 60% infil, but if you go with 80% it will probably last longer for you. You may also want to use 2 outer layers on the spool holder itself. I used 2mm supports in Simplify 3D settings. Used ABS for all parts but PLA should work fine. The clips included snap into the spool holder after you mount the reel to keep it from sliding out during printing. The filament guide is sized for 2.00 outer diameter PTFE tubing. If you have larger tubing you may be able to drill them out a little to fit it.

remixed_from.title: Hinged Box With Latch, Somewhat Parametric and Printable In One Piece

description.text:
There is something mysterious and wonderful about sending an anonymous message and imagining where it may end up. The Drifting Messenger is a way to send anonymous messages (along with a small gift) via air mail. It's a similar idea to sending a postcard or letter by tying it to a helium balloon.
Since the box is (hopefully) still in tact after it lands, the receiver might release it back into the air after getting the message. You may even consider putting in a “travel log” as a way to record the many places that it may travel to!

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

This version took around 16 balloons to lift. You can get plain latex balloons blown up relatively cheaply at a local party store. EDIT: Although there are metallic mylar balloons in the picture, please only use latex balloons! Metallic mylar balloons short out power lines, cause fires and power outages.
Please keep that in mind! Besides, latex balloons are a lot cheaper anyway. If you want to fit more items, then feel free to scale up, and adjust the amount of balloons accordingly. Be careful if you try to scale it down, however, as the hinge may fuse together (see the original Hinged Box from anewsome for further notes).

comments.text: Nice idea but please don't use the metallic mylar balloons, they can short out power lines, cause fires and even power outages. Just stick with the latex balloons.

title: Bed Phone Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: We all have that relatable moment when we feel uncomfortable of holding the phone for too long while laying down or having our phone unexpectedly fall on our faces while watching videos. With Bed Phone Stand, those worries disappear as you do not have to use your hands to hold up your phone any longer.  Inspired by a bed tray and mini tripods, Bed Phone Stand is created to use while in bed. Bed Phone Stand can be adjusted to any smart phone from IPhones to Galaxys, just screw in your specific phone type mount. The adjustable slide enables you to slide your phone from one end to another, that way you can enjoy your videos whether it’s YouTube or Netflix from any angle without feeling constraint to just one position. Bed Phone Stand is comfortable and doesn’t get in the way of your laying down position since it offers enough space to move around without worries. Bed Phone Stand is lightweight, making it easy to transport. Bed Phone Stand is a great way to watch videos on your phone without having to hold the phone the entire time, simply put the video, show or movie, get comfortable, adjust the phone position , get your tea or hot chocolate, lay back and enjoy.

Bed Phone Stand consists of three different things:
  • Phone slider- this thing requires two aluminum tubes/pipes of about 0.7 cm in diameter.
  • Mini tripod- can use any type. Simply glue it to the two phone slider parts.
  • Phone mount- source file cited. Bed Phone Stand can be adjusted to fit other phone mounts. This can be purchased or printed if you want to save money.

In today’s society, it is evident that the majority of the public grapples with a severe phone addiction. Just by walking down the street, one may feel as though they are surrounded by zombies with their heads buried into their smartphones. In order to bring people back into reality, a device must be created to thwart the accessibility of smartphones. The Puzzle Case is a solution which requires the user to perform several steps before accessing the phone. This creates a level of inconvenience that the user would rather avoid, thus preventing him from using the phone. This design is a fusion between an iPhone 6 Plus case and a puzzle box. The case itself is quite large, so the user feels less inclined to hold it in his hand. If each piece is not removed in a specific sequence, the case will be unable to be removed. This requires the user to figure out the puzzle, consequently delaying access to the phone. Ideally these set of circumstances will help to remove users from their phones in order to create a more present and involved society.

description.text:
A small TV for my miniature NES :)
I was lazy on this one, so you have to glue the back and the front together, but maybe I will change this, so one can screw it together (which I would prefer).
I've printed the back not 100%, the pictures are from the first test-print.
The model for the NES is: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:962488
The display is a small 3.5 LCD with a composite input (no special drivers needed) (http://www.amazon.de/ePathChina®-Rückspiegel-Unterstützung-Rückfahrkamera-Einparkhilfe/dp/B00DFYQZFW)
I've changed the electronics inside the LCD, so it will run with only 5V instead of 12V, so now I can connect it to the Rasperry Pinhead and use only 1 USB-Charger to power both at the same time. I've attached a picture of the changed display-pcb for the brave ones who also want to try it ;)
(1 IC out, 1 shortcut)
[+optional 1 resistor out, +1 bridge if the voltage drop is too high and you get no or an unsteady picture]
In case you have some questions regarding the changes on the PCB, write me, I will try to give you answers. I'm planing to integrate some kind of speaker into it in the future. Edit (2016-02-13): Added Raspberry A+ mounting holes and a hole for the USB-Port. Added speaker and speaker-pcb holder.

title: "Compound Bow" Mod for Rubber-Band Bow and Arrow

description.text:
Figured as a first attempt to make something in Sketshup and print it I'd try and turn this bow into a crude compound bow. Actually worked well. Just print the parts and affix onto 'Rubber-Band Bow and Arrow by j_siegel'. Some sanding may be required to get the pulleys to move smoothly.

  • Slide the pully holders over the band knobs on the bow and arrow. They fit snug but some krazy glue helps keep them from moving at all when there is a lot of tension on the band. Try and get the center of the pulleys more or less in the center of the hole.

  • Slide the pulley rod thru the hole in the mount and heat the end pushing down a bit to flare it out but not so tight that it doesn't move. There is a lo of leeway here and should be pretty eays to melt in place yet move.

  • Glue the band holder into the smaller hole on the bow originally used to hold the filament guide. There should be a corrosponding hole on the other end to refit the guide rod (piece of filament), may need to be drilled out a bit. You also may need to snad down the rounded back of the clip so it doesn't hit the bow part to get it to fit into the hole.

  • For the band I used thin elastic cord from the arts and craft store, works great. Tie one end to the small knob on he pulley mount and run it down, thru the holder in the middle under, and back up and over the other pulleys (not thru the center holder when going back up). Then run it in back down again thru the center holder. Pull snug and tie to the knob on the other pulley holder.

  • Put in filamnt guide rod and slide piece. Done.
    • ... also made a "Crossbow" mod which is pretty neat. Will post it soon.

The famous expanding and contracting ball toy that also makes excellent structural support for whatever sparse scaffolding you need. Basically, if you can design it as a geometric solid, you can probably make a collapsible version with this. In a pinch, also doubles as a jack or a reacher-grabber claw. I was looking to build a NautilusX model http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nautilus-X and realized that Thingiverse didn't even have a Hoberman sphere library. It uses one-way snaps might be useful for other projects too. I'm not nearly clever enough to invent the Hoberman sphere. Thanks to Charles Hoberman for the original concept and helpfully detailed drawings.

Print out lots of copies of the plate.  Join those copies together.  The arms snap together so no need for glue or bolts or anything silly like that.  Make sure you have the arms facing the right way, because they don't unsnap together very easily (see picture).  Join three or more arms together with the rings so that they can all rotate independently on different axes.
If you're making an icosahedron (the simplest "sphere"), you'll need 30 plates.  Any more then that and you will probably need to adjust arm lengths, and the positions of the pins.
Until I get enough arms printed to start seriously assembling, this will be a work in progress.

Here's our fourth scan with the MakerBot Digitizer. We're building the Digitizer to be an affordable, simple 3D scanning tool that fits on your desktop and works perfectly with our MakerBot Desktop 3D Printers. This lighthouse we found at a local Thrift Store shows the progress we've made so far on delivering great depth resolution. The lighthouse has subtle textures that are beautifully captured in our scan. Many of the organic textures found on the original model lighthouse can be found in the resulting scan. Note! The downloadable file here is actually much more accurate than the photo indicates. We re-scanned this object with two lasers and got a great result. Click here to stay fully up-to-date on the Digitizer progress in our lab, and check out our blog for the full story on this scan. You can see the full "Digitized!" collection here.
http://store.makerbot.com/digitizer.html

I wanted to use different combinations of letters, to have it look more difficult. I added two examples for a mixed (but still ordered) alphabet. Sadly, the Thingiverse Customizer does not allow for imported STLs.
So for now, you'll have to download this (preferable the Download All Files zip) and start up in OpenSCAD yourself.
Don't be afraid of source code, it only looks scary :) All you have to do is change "ringtext" in the file, and press F6, then File - Export - STL. You may encounter an error like "CGAL error in CGALUtils::applyBinaryOperator" or something like this, and I don't know where this comes from. (Any help is appreciated)
Try rotating the chars around (like bixedwyptaluj to jbixedwyptalu), this helped here every time. Don't use the same letter twice, or you would have to guess which one opens the cryptex.
Only letters from the original ring can be used, so no numbers, Umlauts or other special characters. The object may not be manifold. Just put it through https://netfabb.azurewebsites.net/ or any service or tool of your choosing.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: Just print it the same as the other parts of the Mini ish Cryptex (improved design).

I was about to rebuild the ring from scratch in OpenSCAD when I realized, I could simply reuse it. So for every desired letter, I do:
  • import and center the existing ring (a-m, n-z)
  • rotate it so the desired char is "up"
  • cut out a pie slice
  • rotate the slice according to it's final position in the new ring

description.text:
RepRap Clover is a tiny, low-budget Delta 3D printer. The design was made very simple so anyone can use almost any spare parts they have laying around. It is also very easy to scale and expand on. I encourage you to modify and add onto the files for your own purposes and available materials. Default specs:
Build area: 100mm diameter, ~90mm height
Min Layer height: 0.05
Top printing speed: ~100mm/s
Materials: PLA, Wood filaments Materials Needed:
-4x NEMA17 motors
-1x Hotend, recommended E3D Lite6
-1x Controller, recommended Printrboard
-1x PTFE tube, 4mm OD, 2mm ID
-2x M4 nuts
-1x Printrbot Alu extruder, or printed version found on thingiverse
-6x equal-length rods, or 3 equal length T slots
-6x m3x8 screws
-3x belt and pulley of your choice (default is GT2, 20 tooth pulley)
-6x 15mm steel balls
-18x 6mm diameter, 4mm tall magnets
-2x M3x16 screws
-12x 1/2" 6-32 screws
-12x 6-32 nuts
-3x M8x25 screws
-3x 608 (8x22x7) bearings
-x3 mechanical endstops [More info will be added later, by request]

title: Team Fortress 2 (tf2) RC Sentry Turret Level 1

description.text:
One TF2 sentry turret!
  • Choose between the all in one "HeadPrint" or the separated "FacePrint" and "AmmoDrumPrint". I went with the separate parts so that i could print the face in black and the ammo drum in red.
  • Print 1 of everything else apart from link 2, print 2 of that. Prints can shrink, scaling everything up by 0.5-1% may help. Improved chassis print has hex nut cut outs on servo holders and a stretched neck for greater link clearance. See video for a better explanation.
  • Laser Cut the leg file if possible, otherwise print. The star holes are designed to fit etronix 9g servos, other brands may require some altering to the files. If you don't want to do this, simply attach the legs to the servo horns.
  • Fill With 9g servos, some filing/drilling may be required.
  • Add a microcontroller or RC receiver.
  • 4 AAA batteries in a holder should fit in the large cavity.
  • Wire everything up.
  • Good luck.
  • Watch the video tips, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0PtLBAkk6Bc&ab_channel=CollingwoodsContraptions

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Makerbot standard worked fine for me

Infill:

High on Chassis, Low on Head.

Notes: High infill on the chassis and 3 shells minimum.
2 Shells and a low infill is best for the Head/Ammo,Face.
Point the face up before printing to minimise supports.

description.text:
Here we have my rendition of the Cortana Data Chip. Decided to do this as a bit of fun and see how fine a detail i could achieve on my printer. I would say that the model is about 95% accurate to the one as seen in Halo 3 (i think it looks the best) with the differences being in the plug and the screws ( The detail accurate one would be far too small to print with any clarity)
I printed mine at 50% infill in ABS, any material should work.
Simply print the two files (each side is different) and adhere together, using epoxy, superglue etc. you could be really fancy and put some thin acrylic in between the two halves if you desired. (I didn't on mine, but may in the future. I am also going to paint mine and make it look more realistic. Ill add the photos when i do.
Enjoy
Feel free to post criticism or changes. Also feel free to modify this in anyway you see fit, if you make one, please post it in the make section. P.S I may do a H4 or H5 one if people want it so let me know
I apology about the hideous photo quality also lighting was terrible,will take more tomorrow and update

I saw the Centrifugal Mug Carrier by Ecogeeco and decided to see if I could make my own. It's pretty much the same thing as the SpillNot I've seen from Arbor Scientific. It is sized to fit a standard coffee cup (83 mm diameter, 110 mm tall). You'll need to tie a string or strap to the ring. You put a full cup of water or a mug of coffee and swing this around without any danger of spilling. Unless, of course, you hit someone with it. With a little practice you can swing this in big vertical circles or even in horizontal circles over your head.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

40%

Notes: I printed mine with PLA. Three perimeters and 40% infill. I wanted to make sure the neck was strong enough while swinging this in big circles over my head.

This was created in TinkerCad.You can easily modify it to suit what ever cup you might have. https://tinkercad.com/things/i02pOyl5X81 This was created from:
  • A "Cylinder" (orange) as the base with a squished "Torus thin" (red) to make a lip to keep something from sliding off.
  • A "Torus" (green) to swing it by. This was placed above the center of the base floating in space. It is important that this be centered above the base at the desired height. Then group it with the base so it will stay centered.
  • A "Torus Thin" (blue) was stretched to attach the base to the ring. "Box" holes were used to remove the un-needed bits.
  • A stretched "Half Sphere" was tacked on to make the ring attachment more attractive. This is hidden in the picture below.
NGSS

Students will go online and find commercial science demonstration/lab products or will envision new objects for aiding in science education. They will create these in Tinkercad for 3D printing. In the process, students will learn a little about the underlying scientific phenomena involved as well as constraints in 3D design and printing. If copying the design of an object found online, students will also be tasked with proposing improvements to the original. Objectives
  • Students will be able to demonstrate a device for teaching/learning science.
  • Students will be able to create and print a basic 3D design.
  • Students will be able to evaluate a design, either their own or one they’ve found, and make improvements.
    • Audiences
  • Students in grades 6-12
    • Subjects
  • Science or engineering students
    • Skills/Standards
    NGSS Engineering standards and Science Standards specific to the particular problem
  • NGSS Science and Engineering Practices:
    • Asking questions and defining problems
    • Constructing explanations and designing solutions
  • NGSS Core Ideas: Engineering, Technology and Applications of Science
    • ETS1.A: Defining and Delimiting an Engineering Problem
    • ETS1.B: Developing Possible Solutions
    • ETS1.C: Optimizing the Design Solution
  • NGSS Core Ideas: Science - Standards will vary depending on the problem students select to solve.

• Introduce students to Tinkercad and give them a brief overview. Something similar to the video below. Have students play and create an interesting thing. I typically have students skip the Tinkercad tutorials and dive right in.
  • Share a couple of the students’ creations with the class and talk a bit about the capabilities and limitations of 3D printing.
    • Would these designs be printable?
    • Would support be required?
    • Should it be printed in multiple parts and then assembled?
  • Introduce the Assignment. Create a device to help teach a scientific concept. You can take inspiration from an existing commercially available product or you can create your own.
  • Break students into groups of 2-3 and have them research and/or brainstorm ideas.
  • Students use TInkercad to create models for 3D printing.
  • Print, test model, and share with class for input.
  • Students refine or re-design their models to make improvements.
  • Re-print, test and make improvements as needed.
    • Duration
  • One class period to introduce and create a sample thing in Tinkercad
  • One class period to share designs, discuss 3D printing, and introduce the assignment.
  • One class period for students in groups of 2-3 to brainstorm/research science supply sites for ideas.
  • 1-2 class periods to create models in Tinkercad for printing.
  • One class period for testing and demonstrating to the class.
  • 1-2 class periods to improve on or re-design their objects.

description.text: Here's our fifth scan with the MakerBot Digitizer. We're building the Digitizer to be an affordable, simple 3D scanning tool that fits on your desktop and works perfectly with our MakerBot Desktop 3D Printers. Note! The downloadable file here is actually much more accurate than the photo indicates. We re-scanned this object with two lasers and got a great result. We found this candlestick angel at a local Thrift Store shows the progress we've made so far. Just check out the depth resolution on our angelic 3D model. The scan accurately captures the feathery details of the AngelÃ¢â¬â¢s wing, thanks to the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D ScannerÃ¢â¬â¢s depth resolution specifications. Click here to stay fully up-to-date on the Digitizer progress in our lab, and check out our blog for the full story on this scan. You can see the full "Digitized!" collection here.

description.text: Here's what we'd like to think is an ancient relic: we actually found it at a local thrift store. It's our seventh scan on the MakerBot Digitizer. We're building the Digitizer to be an affordable, simple 3D scanning tool that fits on your desktop and works perfectly with our MakerBot Desktop 3D Printers. This piece shows some more good progress, especially in one important feature: automatically closing the mesh. The Digitizer's software found the bottom of this ancient relic and created a closed flat surface so that the resulting model is watertight, or "manifold" in technical terms. This means this model came directly from the scanner with no cleanup, and now it's ready for 3D printing. Click here to stay fully up-to-date on the Digitizer progress in our lab, and check out our blog for the full story on this scan. You can see the full "Digitized!" collection here.
http://store.makerbot.com/digitizer.html

This is an endstop holder modified from the Prusa Mendel design. When we printed the old one out, the far hole was too close to the edge to render properly, for no particular design reason we could discern.  We extended the end of this part by about 2mm and it prints a much better looking part, even with RepSnapper. 
Also, this part is great for mounting TechZone's monotronics - use two.
This represents an atom of gold. It has 79 electrons. Each of the 6 shells is independently articulating on a gimbal system.

I printed this on my Ultimaker at .1mm layer height and it came out great. The rings are lightly locked in place when first removed off the bed. Simply force each ring to rotate on is axis and after a revolution or two it should spin smoothly

comments.text:
Dont turn the threads down, that makes it more unstable and incredibly slow, that kid is an idiot. . Make sure u update slicer to the current version and dont use the dev pack, its unstable and for advanced users only. It also has memory leaks so sometimes a reboot can fix it. Dont use slic3r unless u want fancy infill or surface textures. I use Cura for basic prints and slicer for heavy modification like internal reflections via over extruding one layer, you can get really technical with Slic3r but u need to know what ur doing or ur gonna waste pla.
Slic3r is most stable when it has one less thread than your core count. Its fastest with 1 or 1 threads above your core count, (about 1 thread for 4 cores, so 8core=+2 threads.
comments.author: KyleMFSpurgeon

comments.text: Turn down the number of threads to 1 in the advanced tab of slic3r

description.text: Here's our sixth scan with the MakerBot Digitizer. We're building the Digitizer to be an affordable, simple 3D scanning tool that fits on your desktop and works perfectly with our MakerBot Desktop 3D Printers. This friendly feline has a matte texture that is perfect for scanning, as glossy surfaces can overexpose the camera's light sensor, making surfaces difficult to capture. Our cat fit within Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner's size parameters, as it can scan objects up to the size of an 8" by 8" cylinder. Click here to stay fully up-to-date on the Digitizer progress in our lab, and check out our blog for the full story on this scan. You can see the full "Digitized!" collection here.

You will need an arduino, stepmotors i.e. NE17, stepmotor drivers, 12v powersupply for stepmotordrivers, some signal wires and battery 9v for arduino power itself.
You may buy most of it at SPARKFUN.com or ADAFRUIT.com (at least a year ago).

title: Beer Yeast Separation Funnel using Erlenmeyer  [Customizable]

description.text:
This build turns an Erlenmeyer flask into a separation funnel. When it's done, it should be possible to extract the different layers of the yeast cake into individual flasks. It is in the stage of prototyping, and I need to learn beer yeast washing as I go along.
Any comment/suggestions are more than welcome !

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: You want to print the insert single walled so that it breaks away easily, but make sure it is closed, so that the silicone does not flow in. The clamp must be 100% infill to be strong enough. Before you print it all, print the template and see if it fits on top of your Erlenmeyer flask, it should stretch a bit when put it on.

comments.text: I like the idea here.  I think you will need to somehow allow air into the headspace to prevent a vacuum.  I don't think that the yeast will come out very well because air will need to come in.  You could put another opening in the mold to allow for a solid tube to get air in the headspace.  I am also a little concerned about sanitizing.  3D printing creates a lot of little crevasses that may be hard to sanitize.   This design has some potential.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/aLk8alTa1I3

Here's our eighth scan with the MakerBot Digitizer. We're building the Digitizer to be an affordable, simple 3D scanning tool that fits on your desktop and works perfectly with our MakerBot Desktop 3D Printers. Other 3D scanning options often deliver files with missing data. Models come filled with holes, which makes it almost impossible to process for 3D printing or use for additional 3D modeling. Repairing all the holes is crucial but it can be a time-consuming process. In order to fulfill on the promise of time savings and ease of use, we engineered the MakerBot Digitizer to automatically repair any holes and streamline the capture and print process. The result is that you can send every scan to your 3D printer without any repair work. Click here to stay fully up-to-date on the Digitizer progress in our lab, and check out our blog for the full story on this scan. You can see the full "Digitized!" collection here.
http://store.makerbot.com/digitizer.html

author: Wjgold

description.text:
I was having issues with my EZstruder slipping trying to grip filament so I wanted to increase the grip by increasing the tension caused by the spring. So I just created a 2mm spacer that the spring can rest on.
It gives it enough torque now that if it's being told to extruder, but gets too much "backpressure" from trying to extrude too much for the motor to handle the motor will skip, instead of the filament slipping. I had previously tried a 3mm spacer but that caused too much torque and a failed print after 3 hours :( This 2mm spacer though I have successfully ran a 12 hour print ( the vase above) with a .5mm nozzle at .15mm layer height at 88mm/s. If there was any filament slippage it definitely wasn't obvious from the print, it turned out GREAT!

I printed it at .15mm layer height with a .5mm nozzle... But you can print it however your printer can, it doesn't have to be exact. It's just lifting the base where the spring rests to put more tension on the filament.   
It is semi-difficult to get in there with the spring, but it is possible without removing the arm first! I just held it in place and pushed it onto the arm first, then used a screwdriver to pry the top of the spring into the upper rest.
